trans-unit.source: PowerShell Snippets
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Snippets

trans-unit.source: PowerShell is an awesome scripting, automation, and management tool for Hyper-V. Here is a toolbox for exploring some of the cool things it can do!
trans-unit.target: PowerShell is an awesome scripting, automation, and management tool for Hyper-V. Here is a toolbox for exploring some of the cool things it can do!

trans-unit.source: All Hyper-V management requires running as administrator so assume all scripts and snippets must be run as administrator from a Hyper-V Administrator account.
trans-unit.target: All Hyper-V management requires running as administrator so assume all scripts and snippets must be run as administrator from a Hyper-V Administrator account.

trans-unit.source: If you aren't sure if you have the right permissions, type Get-VM and if it runs with no errors, you're ready to go.
trans-unit.target: If you aren't sure if you have the right permissions, type Get-VM and if it runs with no errors, you're ready to go.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Direct tools
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Direct tools

trans-unit.source: All of the scripts and snippets in this section will rely on the following basics.
trans-unit.target: All of the scripts and snippets in this section will rely on the following basics.

trans-unit.source: Requirements :
trans-unit.target: Requirements :

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Direct.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Direct.

trans-unit.source: Windows 10 guest and host OS.
trans-unit.target: Windows 10 guest and host OS.

trans-unit.source: Common Variables : $VMName -- this is a string with the VMName.
trans-unit.target: Common Variables : $VMName -- this is a string with the VMName.

trans-unit.source: See a list of available VMs with Get-VM $cred -- Credential for the guest OS.
trans-unit.target: See a list of available VMs with Get-VM $cred -- Credential for the guest OS.

trans-unit.source: Can be populated using $cred = Get-Credential
trans-unit.target: Can be populated using $cred = Get-Credential

trans-unit.source: Check if the guest has booted
trans-unit.target: Check if the guest has booted

trans-unit.source: Hyper-V Manager doesn't give you visibility into the guest operating system which often makes it difficult to know whether the guest OS has booted.
trans-unit.target: Hyper-V Manager doesn't give you visibility into the guest operating system which often makes it difficult to know whether the guest OS has booted.

trans-unit.source: Use this command to check whether the guest has booted.
trans-unit.target: Use this command to check whether the guest has booted.

trans-unit.source: Outcome Prints a friendly message declaring the state of the guest OS.
trans-unit.target: Outcome Prints a friendly message declaring the state of the guest OS.

trans-unit.source: Script locking until the guest has booted
trans-unit.target: Script locking until the guest has booted

trans-unit.source: The following function waits uses the same principle to wait until PowerShell is available in the guest (meaning the OS has booted and most services are running) then returns.
trans-unit.target: The following function waits uses the same principle to wait until PowerShell is available in the guest (meaning the OS has booted and most services are running) then returns.

trans-unit.source: Outcome Prints a friendly message and locks until the connection to the VM succeeds.
trans-unit.target: Outcome Prints a friendly message and locks until the connection to the VM succeeds.

trans-unit.source: Succeeds silently.
trans-unit.target: Succeeds silently.

trans-unit.source: Script locking until the guest has a network
trans-unit.target: Script locking until the guest has a network

trans-unit.source: With PowerShell Direct it is possible to get connected to a PowerShell session inside a virtual machine before the virtual machine has received an IP address.
trans-unit.target: With PowerShell Direct it is possible to get connected to a PowerShell session inside a virtual machine before the virtual machine has received an IP address.

trans-unit.source: * Outcome * Locks until a DHCP lease is recieved.
trans-unit.target: * Outcome * Locks until a DHCP lease is recieved.

trans-unit.source: Since this script is not looking for a specific subnet or IP address, it works no matter what network configuration you're using.
trans-unit.target: Since this script is not looking for a specific subnet or IP address, it works no matter what network configuration you're using.

trans-unit.source: Succeeds silently.
trans-unit.target: Succeeds silently.

trans-unit.source: Managing credentials with PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Managing credentials with PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Hyper-V scripts frequently require handling credentials for one or more virtual machines, Hyper-V host, or both.
trans-unit.target: Hyper-V scripts frequently require handling credentials for one or more virtual machines, Hyper-V host, or both.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple ways you can achieve this when working with PowerShell Direct or standard PowerShell remoting:
trans-unit.target: There are multiple ways you can achieve this when working with PowerShell Direct or standard PowerShell remoting:

trans-unit.source: The first (and simplest) way is to have the same user credentials be valid in the host and the guest or local and remote host.
trans-unit.target: The first (and simplest) way is to have the same user credentials be valid in the host and the guest or local and remote host.

trans-unit.source: This is quite easy if you are logging in with your Microsoft account - or if you are in a domain environment.
trans-unit.target: This is quite easy if you are logging in with your Microsoft account - or if you are in a domain environment.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario you can just run Invoke-Command -VMName "test" {get-process}.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario you can just run Invoke-Command -VMName "test" {get-process}.

trans-unit.source: Let PowerShell prompt you for credentials If your credentials do not match you will automatically get a credential prompt allowing you to provide the appropriate credentials for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Let PowerShell prompt you for credentials If your credentials do not match you will automatically get a credential prompt allowing you to provide the appropriate credentials for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Store credentials in a variable for reuse.
trans-unit.target: Store credentials in a variable for reuse.

trans-unit.source: Running a simple command like this:
trans-unit.target: Running a simple command like this:

trans-unit.source: Will mean that you only get prompted once per script/PowerShell session for your credentials.
trans-unit.target: Will mean that you only get prompted once per script/PowerShell session for your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Code your credentials into your scripts.
trans-unit.target: Code your credentials into your scripts.

trans-unit.target: Don't do this for any real workload or system

trans-unit.target: Warning: _Do not do this in a production system.

trans-unit.target: Do not do this with real passwords._

trans-unit.target: Grossly insecure - but useful for testing.

trans-unit.target: Now you get no prompts at all in this session.
